revised_title: The Role of Acetylcholine in Ciliary Movement in Mytilus edulis
tldr: This study investigates the role of acetylcholine in the ciliary movement of Mytilus edulis, a type of mussel. Acetylcholine, a neurotransmitter, was found to be present in the mussel's gill plates and was shown to control the ciliary movement. The study found that low concentrations of acetylcholine and the drug eserine increased ciliary movement, while high concentrations and d-tubocurarine decreased it. These findings support the theory that acetylcholine acts as a local hormone in non-nervous tissue.
